facts.text: The appellant company was permitted under two separate agreements both dated 1944-09-14 with the Maharaja of Jeypore to collect sleepers and scantlings from logs of sal trees marked by the forest department in the Ramgiri Forest and Omerkote Nowrangpur range in the Jeypore Estate for the period 1944-07-01 to 1950-06-30 in consideration of royalty payments.

anchor.surface_text: For the period July 1, 1944, to June 30, 1950, the appellant companypany was permitted under two separate agreements both dated September 14, 1944, with the Maharaja of Jeypore to companylect sleepers and scantlings approved by the companypany form logs of sal trees marked by the forest department, in the Ramgiri Forest and Omerkote Nowrangpur range in the Jeypore Estate, in companysideration of the companypare agreeing to pay as royalty specified percentages of the price at which the sleepers and Scantligns were supplied by the companypany to the Indian railways.

facts.text: Company offered by letter dated 1950-01-16 to Dewan of Jeypore to pay enhanced royalty for period 1948-06-01 to 1950-06-30 in consideration of renewal of agreements.

anchor.surface_text: By a letter dated January 16, 1950, addressed to the Dewan of Jeypore the companypany offered to pay enhanced royalty for the period June 1, 1948, to June 30, 1950, in companysiderate of the Estate granting renewal of the agreements which were about to expire.

facts.text: Collector of Koraput sanctioned renewal of original agreement for one year from 1950-07-01 to 1951-06-30 by order dated 1950-04-03 under section 31(a) of Orissa Preservation of Private Forests Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The companylector of Koraput who was the authority to sanction the grant or renewal of the agreement under section 3 1  a  of the Orissa Preservations of Private Forests Act, 1947, by order dated April 3, 1950, sanctioned renewal of the original agreement for one year from July 1, 1950, to June 30, 1951.

facts.text: Fresh agreement executed on 1952-06-13 for term of three years effective from 1951-07-01 granting right to cut sal trees marked by Estate's forest department, convert to sleepers and scantlings, and remove them.

anchor.surface_text: A fresh agreements was there after executed on June 13, 1952 for a term of three years with effect from July 1, 1951 under which companypany was granted the right to cut sal trees marked by the Estates forest department in the arrear agreed upon and to companyvert the same into sleepers and scantlings and to remove them.

facts.text: Agreement dated 1952-06-13 provided company to pay Estate minimum Rs 40,000 annually at rates in clause 6 for sleepers and scantlings, not to be altered during term.

anchor.surface_text: The agreements provided that the companypany would pay to Estate subject to a minimum of Rs 40,000 annually  which would number be altered during the term of the agreement  at the rates specified in clause 6 for different types of sleepers and scatlings mentioned therein.

facts.text: During negotiations for extension from 1951-07-01, company agreed to pay enhanced royalty rates for period 1943-07-01 to 1950-06-30 if extended for at least three years, at Rs. 69,000 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of negotiations for extensions of the agreement from July 1, 1951, the companypany agreed to pay royalty enhanced rates for the period July 1 1943 to June 30, 1950, on companyditions that the agreement was extended for at least three years. This worked at the rate of Rs. 69,000 per annum.

facts.text: Company offered by letter dated 1951-03-22 to pay additional Rs. 9,000 annually in addition to Rs. 69,000.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany then offered by its letter dated March 22, 1951, to pay an additional amount of Rs. 9,000 annually in addition to Rs. 69,000 already agreed to be paid.

facts.text: By letter dated 1952-06-10, company confirmed agreement to pay additional Rs. 83,000 annually during term of lease subject to signing lease in terms of draft enclosed with 1951-06-09 letter.

anchor.surface_text: By another letter dated June 10, 1952 it was companyfirmed that subject to a lease being signed in the terms of the draft enclosed with the companypany letter dated June 9, 1951, the companypany agreed to pay additional amounts in the aggregate at the rate of Rs. 83,000 annually during the term of the lease.

facts.text: Additional payments covenant not incorporated in agreement dated 1952-06-13.

anchor.surface_text: A companyvenient about the additional payments offered to be made by the companypany was however number incorporated in the agreement dated June 13, 1952.

facts.text: In income-tax assessment year 1953-54, company claimed deduction of Rs. 83,157 paid during year of account as additional to royalty under 1952-06-13 agreement under section 10(2)(xv) of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In proceeding for assessment of income-tax in the assessment year 1953-54, the claim of the companypany to deduct Rs. 83,157 pending during the year of account in addition to the royalty stipulated to be under the agreement dated June 13, 1952 as an allowable expenditure under section 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act was rejected by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the claim to deduct Rs. 83,157.

anchor.surface_text: ...was rejected by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner reversed ITO order and allowed deduction holding additional payments were additional royalty for acquiring logs, part of cost of stock-in-trade.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax was reversed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who held that the agreement to pay amounts of money addition to royalty stipulated to be paid under the formal agreement were additional royalty solely for the purpose of acquiring logs to be companyverted into sleeper for sale and the payments represented the prime companyt of the companypanys stock-in-trade.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed AAC order.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the Income-tax Officer, the Income-tax Appellant Tribunal companyfirmed the order to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court of Calcutta: whether Rs. 83,517 allowable as revenue expenditure based on facts and three enclosures to assessee's letter dated 1954-07-08.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then drew up a statement and submitted the following question for the opinion of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, and on the companyrect interpretations of the three enclosure to the letter of the assessee dated the 8th day of July 1954, to the Income-tax Officer companycerned the sum of Rs. 83,517 was allowable as an expenditure of a revenue nature ?

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative, holding expenditure was capital not revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded its answer on the question in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs, sustaining High Court on alternative ground that additional payments were for securing renewal/extension, benefit of enduring nature, capital expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals, therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: High Court assumed royalty under 1952-06-13 agreement and additional payments same character; company got right to extract sleepers not purchase standing timber.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court the expenditure incurred by the companypany was of the nature of capital expenditure and number revenue. In reaching their companyclusion the learned judges assumed that the royalty payable under the agreement dated June 13, 1952 and the additional payment agreed to be made by companyrespondence between the companypany and the Dewan of the Estate were of the same character, and that by the agreement dated June 13, 1952, the companypany did number purchase standing timber, but it was given a right to extract sleepers.

facts.text: Expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for business, not capital or personal, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: The expenditure in question was, it is companymon ground, laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business, and it was number an allowance of the nature described in clauses  i  to  xiv  of sub- section  2  of section 10.

facts.text: Supreme Court held royalty under 1952-06-13 agreement was revenue expenditure for acquiring stock-in-trade; ITO only disallowed additional amounts for back royalty 1948-06-01 to 1950-06-30.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer did number disallow the royalty stipulated to be paid under the terms of the agreement dated June 13, 1952 he only disallowed the additional amounts which related to what was called back royalty for the period July 1, 1948, to June 30, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Royalty under formal agreement is for stock-in-trade while additional payments are separate offers for renewal.

holdings.text: The High Court was also not right in holding that the royalty paid under the agreement was of the nature of capital expenditure. Under the terms of the agreement dated June 13, 1952 the company had made an arrangements for obtaining what was it stock-in-trade, and money spent for acquiring stock-in-trade of the business is revenue expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement grants right to cut marked trees and convert to sleepers/scantlings which are stock-in-trade; cost to acquire stock-in-trade is revenue expenditure.

holdings.text: But we are of the view that the answer recorded on the alternative ground which appealed to the High Court must be sustained. The additional payments were worked out on the basis of total royalty paid during the period two years under the earlier agreements... payment of premium is consideration of the owner of property agreeing to grant a right to take and remove the stock-in-trade of the taxpayer is in the nature of capital expenditure. We, therefore, agree with the High Court on the alternative ground which appeal to them.

anchor.surface_text: But we are of the view that the answer recorded on the alternative ground which appealed to the High companryt must be sustained. The additional payments were worked out on the basis of total royalty paid during the period two years under the earlier agreements, i.e., from June 1, 1948, to June 30, 1950, and were offered to be paid in consideration of the Estate agreeing to grant renewal of those agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional payments were conditional offers to secure longer-term renewal/extension akin to premium for lease conferring enduring benefit; not part of stock-in-trade price.

holdings.text: The expenditure in question was, it is common ground, laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business, and it was not an allowance of the nature described in clauses (i) to (xiv) of sub-section (2) of section 10.

anchor.surface_text: According to the High companyrt, the companypany had to enter the forests, to wait for certain trees to be marked, and then to cut such trees according to its requirements for the supply of sleepers to the railway and others, as and when it liked, within the specified period of three years, and that what was acquired under the agreement was number stock-in-trade, but the right to acquire it and upon the principle laid down by the House of Lords in Hood-Barrs v Inland Revenue Commissioners, the companypany acquired a capital asset of an enduring nature.

precedents.cited_proposition: acquisition of the right to enter forests, wait for trees to be marked, and cut them as required over a period of three years constitutes acquisition of a capital asset of enduring nature rather than stock-in-trade
